6.speaker: Wyll
6.text: 'O Balduran, founder due veneration, his guardian dragon Ansur, tremendous in worth. A saviour below, our eternal elation.'

18.speaker: Player
18.text: 'The Legend of Ansur'. What do you make of the tale?

63.speaker: Wyll
63.text: It's not just a tale. It's a history.

40.speaker: Player
40.text: Don't tell me you're taking that poem seriously.

19.speaker: Wyll
19.text: Why shouldn't I? It must be more than a myth, given who carried it.

23.speaker: Player
23.text: Can you cut to the chase? I don't speak bard.

27.speaker: Wyll
27.text: 'The Legend of Ansur' isn't just a poem - it's a history.

90.speaker: Player
90.text: I've heard all manner of songs and tall tales. This one's new to me.

56.speaker: Wyll
56.text: And to me. But given who carried it, I think it's more than just a myth.

7.speaker: Wyll
7.text: Curse that rotten devil and her forked tongue, trying to set Florrick against me. She's a damnable inferno of chaos.

41.speaker: Wyll
41.text: What matters now is that Florrick saw sense - and we know our path forward.

50.speaker: Wyll
50.text: We'll finish what my father couldn't. We'll awaken Ansur, the Heart of the Gate.

34.speaker: Player
34.text: It's an incredible tale. What do you make of it?

82.speaker: Player
82.text: I can't believe you're taking this dragon poem seriously.

59.speaker: Wyll
59.text: Why shouldn't I? I have no reason to doubt Florrick's word, and neither do you.

8.speaker: Wyll
8.text: Why shouldn't I? I have no reason to doubt Eltan's word, and neither do you.

15.speaker: Player
15.text: How about a translation? I don't speak bard.

69.speaker: Player
69.text: I've heard all manner of songs and tall tales. This one's new to me.

49.speaker: Player
49.text: Do you really think a dragon's been living under Baldur's Gate?

55.speaker: Wyll
55.text: I do. And so did my father.

0.speaker: Player
0.text: A big enough dragon could annihilate scores of cultists. We need Ansur's help.

93.speaker: Player
93.text: Ravengard's dead and he's still got you running errands. What a daddy's boy.

9.speaker: Wyll
9.text: 'Daddy' held the key to a living weapon that could melt that brain into goo.

28.speaker: Narrator
28.text: *Wyll's mind links with yours. He learns of Mizora's meddling - and Eltan's defeat.*

17.speaker: Wyll
17.text: Curse that rotten devil and her forked tongue, setting Eltan against me!

43.speaker: Wyll
43.text: We've felled a potential ally - but it's Mizora's hands that are stained with the blood.

32.speaker: Narrator
32.text: *Wyll's mind links with yours. He learns of Mizora's meddling - and Florrick's defeat.*

66.speaker: Wyll
66.text: Curse that rotten devil and her forked tongue, setting Florrick against me!

60.speaker: Wyll
60.text: We've felled our truest ally in the city - but it's Mizora's hands that are stained with the blood.

74.speaker: Wyll
74.text: Gods above. If any good's come of this battle, it lies in that legend.

88.speaker: Player
88.text: It's an incredible tale. What do you make of it?

61.speaker: Player
61.text: I can't believe you're taking this dragon poem seriously.

58.speaker: Player
58.text: How about a translation? I don't speak bard.

11.speaker: Player
11.text: I've heard all manner of songs and tall tales. This one's new to me.

48.speaker: Wyll
48.text: What in the Hells was she thinking, to go spewing such treacherous drivel?

62.speaker: Wyll
62.text: Let's talk with Mizora when we camp. I want answers.

1.speaker: Wyll
1.text: I am her pathway to power. If I were to become duke, she thinks she'd be calling the shots.

89.speaker: Player
89.text: It's still an option worth considering. You could do so much good as a duke.

77.speaker: Wyll
77.text: I've - entertained the idea. I'd sooner end my own life than let Mizora guide Baldur's Gate to ruin.

13.speaker: Player
13.text: All the more reason to avoid it. She could put you up to almost anything.

33.speaker: Wyll
33.text: She could try. But I'd sooner end my own life than lead Baldur's Gate to ruin.

29.speaker: Wyll
29.text: Imagine the evils I could vanquish, the alliances I could build as a Grand Duke.

10.speaker: Wyll
10.text: That presumes, of course, the people would welcome a duke with the face of a devil.

24.speaker: Wyll
24.text: Not a matter to take lightly. And not one to be decided today.

73.speaker: Player
73.text: The city's falling apart. A devil advisor could do it some good.

64.speaker: Wyll
64.text: Heh - I'd sooner end my own life than let Mizora guide Baldur's Gate to ruin.

30.speaker: Wyll
30.text: Still, I've - entertained the idea. Imagine the evils I could vanquish, the alliances I could build.

45.speaker: Wyll
45.text: It's not just a legend. It's a history.

21.speaker: Wyll
21.text: Consider this: 'To Wyrmway 'neath prison's deepest level.' That must mean Wyrm's Rock prison - that's where we'll find the entrance to this 'Wyrmway'.

68.speaker: Wyll
68.text: Then this: 'With the shock of a true hero's spark flickers, the torches alight! And wyrm's eyes shall awake aglitter.' To open the way, we'll need to spark torches.

67.speaker: Wyll
67.text: This dragon Ansur was Balduran's ally. We'd be fools to let him sleep while the Dead Three's chosen raze the city.

46.speaker: Narrator
46.text: *Your mind tingles as it opens to Wyll. He learns of Mizora's meddling - and Florrick's tale of the dragon Ansur.*

12.speaker: Wyll
12.text: Curse that rotten devil and her forked tongue, trying to set Eltan against me. She's a damnable inferno of chaos.

36.speaker: Wyll
36.text: What matters now is that Eltan saw sense - and we know our path forward.

52.speaker: Wyll
52.text: Curse that rotten devil and her forked tongue, trying to set Eltan against me. She's a damnable inferno of chaos.

54.speaker: Wyll
54.text: Curse that rotten devil and her forked tongue, setting Eltan against me!

72.speaker: Narrator
72.text: *Your mind tingles as it opens to Wyll. He learns of Mizora's meddling - and Florrick's tale of the dragon Ansur.*

14.speaker: Wyll
14.text: Curse that rotten devil and her forked tongue, trying to set Florrick against me. She's a damnable inferno of chaos.

92.speaker: Wyll
92.text: Curse that rotten devil and her forked tongue, setting Florrick against me!

94.speaker: Wyll
94.text: We'll finish what my father couldn't. We'll awaken Ansur, the Heart of the Gate.

39.speaker: Wyll
39.text: 'O Balduran, founder due veneration, his guardian dragon Ansur, tremendous in worth. A saviour below, our eternal elation.'

47.speaker: Player
47.text: It's an incredible tale. What do you make of it?

25.speaker: Player
25.text: I can't believe you're taking this dragon poem seriously.

51.speaker: Wyll
51.text: Why shouldn't I? I have no reason to doubt my father's word, and neither do you.

81.speaker: Player
81.text: How about a translation? I don't speak bard.

22.speaker: Player
22.text: I've heard all manner of songs and tall tales. This one's new to me.

75.speaker: Wyll
75.text: I disappointed him once. I won't do it again.

42.speaker: Player
42.text: Do you really think a dragon's been living under Baldur's Gate?

70.speaker: Wyll
70.text: I do. And so does my father.

57.speaker: Wyll
57.text: Go on, read the Legend of Ansur. Then we can plan our next steps.

85.speaker: Player
85.text: A big enough dragon could annihilate scores of cultists. We need Ansur's help.

65.speaker: Player
65.text: Ravengard's already got you wrapped around his little finger. What a daddy's boy.

5.speaker: Wyll
5.text: 'Daddy' just gave us the key to a living weapon that could melt that brain into goo.

53.speaker: Wyll
53.text: Go on, read the Legend of Ansur. Unless you're too busy dreaming up new insults, in which case, let me save you some time:

44.speaker: Wyll
44.text: 'Soldier's Pet'. 'Papa's Prince'. 'Duke's Little Rich Boy'. 'The Babe of Frontiers'.
